video.title: Learn Unity - Beginner's Game Development Tutorial
video.description:
Learn to develop games using the Unity game engine in this complete course for beginners. This course will get you up and running with Unity. Free game assets included!

✏️ Course developed by Fahir from Awesome Tuts. Check out his channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC5c-DuzPdH9iaWYdI0v0uzw

⭐️ Resources ⭐️
(To download assets you may have to right click the link, copy it, and then paste it into a new tab.)
🔗 Unity Introduction Project Assets: http://cdn.freecodecamp.org/youtube/unity-course/Unity%20Introduction%20Project%20Assets.zip
🔗 Unity Introduction Project: http://cdn.freecodecamp.org/youtube/unity-course/Unity%20Introduction%20Project.zip
🔗 Monster Chase Game Assets: http://cdn.freecodecamp.org/youtube/unity-course/Monster%20Chase%20Assets.zip
🔗 Complete Monster Chase Game: http://cdn.freecodecamp.org/youtube/unity-course/Monster%20Chase.zip

topLevelComment.author: Centuri
topLevelComment.text: Around 2:30:00 what is the advantage of putting variables in private and then using getters/setters to get to them instead of just assigning them as public?

replies.author: Centuri
replies.text: @delinear ok, I see, thank you for the answer!

replies.author: delinear
replies.text:
One reason is that it's less likely you'll accidentally use an assignment instead of a comparison when you're "in the zone" and end up accidentally overwriting your variable and having a hard time tracking down the bug (then kicking yourself when you realise what you've done).

Another reason is you have the value encapsulated, so if you need to perform other operations on it, you only need to change the code in one place. Say you're writing a game, and you have a dozen different enemies who all drop a fixed amount of gold when they die, so you put that in a variable and call it from a bunch of places. Now let's say you have a special event running for a month where you want enemies to drop extra gold - if you've used getters, you can factor the extra gold into the getter in one place. If you've used public variables, you'd have to update every instance where you'd directly accessed the variable (and just end up creating your own getter anyway).

There are other reasons to use them too, and it's worth reading up on setters/getters/accessors, but also if you decide you genuinely don't need them and the code is more readable/maintainable without them, that's fine too. They're just one more tool you can use.

Well if anyone has any issue with this, here's what I found: 

"The general rule of thumb is to place all keyboard/mouse input into the Update method and not the FixedUpdate method. The reason for this is because FixedUpdate is not a frame by frame process, but is called at fixed time increments which can be more or less calls in a certain frame period.



Input data is determined every frame, so in FixedUpdate where it can run in-between frames, skip frames, etc. you have the possibility of losing input. Instead, move your input code to the Update method which is called every frame. You will no longer lose input.



The issue with setting your physics calls in Update is because all physics code should be placed in FixedUpdate. As Update can run faster or slower than the physics system in your game, placing physics-based calls in it can have unexpected results."

These are specific to Unity. In many areas of software development there is a concept of “framework”, which usually means something (the framework) “calls your code”. So that it can know how to call your code, the framework wants you to implement functions with certain names and signatures.

Game engines like Unity work as frameworks, they ask you to define these certain special functions, and the engine calls them at defined times (which Unity documentation will explain when, for example “Update” is on every frame).

replies.author: Ches Martin
replies.text:
Often you don’t want to expose the data to other code, outside the class, especially the ability to change it (set). One of the main ideas of object-oriented programming is that classes wrap simple data with *behavior* and it’s the class’s responsibility to define the behavior logic.

For example, say you start your game with a Player class and give it an ageInYears field (variable), and you just ask the user to input an age in years. Later you decide to make Player have a birthdate. So now you can calculate ageInYears from the birthdate instead. That logic can be defined in the class, and nothing else should be allowed to set ageInYears from outside because it might not match the birthdate with correct logic.

If you used `ageInYears { get }` from the beginning, then code outside Player can only get it through a function/method call instead of reading the variable directly. When you add birthdate, you change the `ageInYears { get }` to a `int ageInYears()` method with the birthdate logic, and old outside code that used the getter still works, nothing breaks.

topLevelComment.author: leeo iou
topLevelComment.text: I appreciate your effort. However, I would like to warn new game developers to go to engines like Unreal. As someone who used Unity for over 8 years, I fear for the future of this engine. Bunch of unfinished services and packages of substandard quality. With the rough game market, you will not stand out using unity. Unreal engine is stable with vastly superior tools and actually work. Things look nearly perfect just out of the box. I only started using unreal engine last 2 years and I never looked back at unity. If you want to just goof around with game dev then you can use unity, but if you want to be a professional and make money from not just games, but other 3d products, then stay the hell away from unity.

replies.author: ReactGA
replies.text:
@leeo iou  though there are games like:  the elder's scroll, hitman, assassin's Creed e.t.c that are arguably AAA but like u said earlier, garbage collector is a huge mess.
And I agree that UE was made to be a game engine from day 1 unlike unity (that just introduce some of the features over a decade later). i.e visual scripting, visual material editor, post processing, even something as simple as a realistic day-night system (comparing UE's skysphere to unity's skybox) and the list goes on.

replies.author: leeo iou
replies.text: @ReactGA Hello, you talk all this good game about unity, but where are the results? That is what unreal engine produces. Gears 5, the upcoming PES, fortnite, etc. Big companies know what they are doing, that is why they adopt unreal. Name me one AAA multiplayer multi-million selling console/PC game made with unity. It doesn't exist. Last I checked HDRP was a buggy mess that would fold-up in any real project that would ship to production. Why do you think unity are so obsessed with 3 minute demos? That's where they can flex their muscles. I have been developing games for nearly 20 years and I can see through that. It's not just graphics that makes unreal engine superior, it is by far a more stable engine that has solid foundation built by excellent minds. Unity has always had questionable developers given the buggy pre-alpha poorly architected products and "features" that they continuously ship. Unreal engine's flaws are the lack of c# adoption and not as good documentation as unity. The documentation aspect is changing tho.

replies.author: ReactGA
replies.text:
@leeo iou well about floating point accuracy, the simple simple solution is to move the world relative to the player's movement input so the player remains at the world center instead of moving the player around the world.

Also about graphics, fine unreal might be better but it's just slightly because of unity's HDRP can also perfectly achieve photorealistic rendering/graphics.

replies.author: leeo iou
replies.text: @ReactGA Fair enough. UE is for really advanced developers that are targeting AAA quality. Developers that have powerful laptops/pcs that can handle load. I will not recommend using UE4 to make flappy bird or candy-crush. If you want to make proper games or visualisation products for architects and engineers, UE4 is the way to go. Unity's graphics/rendering system is inferior, it's handling of garbage in real time is bad, it's floating point system is bad for open world games, I can go on and on and pick unity apart but trust me, it's not worth it. If you feel comfortable with unity, then by all means, keep using it.
